title-group.article-title: Uncertainty analysis for multilayer water vapor transmission test method: As exemplified by testing highly permeable membranes

author-notes.corresp: Marcin Pazera, CENTRIA, Moon Township, PA 15108, USA. Email: martin.pazera@gmail.com

abstract.p: This is a follow-up to the article “Multilayer Test Method for Water Vapor Transmission Testing of Construction Materials” in which the authors discussed the development of an alternative approach to the standardized ASTM E96:2010 test method when testing highly permeable materials. The approach denoted as a “multilayer” water vapor transmission test method involves testing simultaneously several stacked material layers each separated by an equivalent air gaps. Determining uncertainties for a novel test method is critical to establish the accuracy of the single test and the estimate for the mean value of the measured property. This is of particular importance for a multilayer experimental system that includes several test specimens and multitude of temperature and relative humidity sensors. The measurements obtained from the experiment include continuous weight readings for the whole system and continuous temperature and relative humidity readings obtained near the opposing specimen surfaces. The authors identify all contributing sources of uncertainty and describe the general approach to uncertainty analysis in the multilayer water vapor transmission test method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The novel approach referred to as a “multilayer test” involves simultaneously testing several vertically stacked specimens (Pazera and Salonvaara, 2012). Sensors mounted near the surface of the tested specimens provide continuous temperature and relative humidity (RH/T) readings, which are used in calculating partial pressure of water vapor. The stacked test assembly is placed on the analytic balance and continuous mass measurements for the system are used to calculate the mass flux. The continuous RH/T readings at opposing surfaces of each layer are used to calculate the partial pressure of water vapor. Permeance is calculated from the mass flux and the difference in the partial pressure of water vapor. The multilayer test method builds on a traditional (standardized) approach to water vapor transmission (WVT) testing of construction materials often referred to as the “cup” test method and described in detail in the ASTM E96:2010 (2010) standard. The multilayer test is essentially a series of cup test measurements performed at the same time with different boundary conditions for each layer. The benefits from the multilayer test strategy include reduction of the measurement period, generation of larger number of data points, and reduction of the required resources (e.g. less test chambers required) when compared to the standardized ASTM E96:2010 (2010) test “cup” method.

The uncertainty analysis should be part of any new test method. At early stages of test method development, sensitivity study or “Ruggedness Study” should be performed to quantify significance of factors that may influence the experiment. For a multilayer WVT test involving several specimens and multitude of sensors, it is critical that all sources of uncertainty and the uncertainty propagation be carefully considered. This article is focused on determining the uncertainty propagation in multilayer WVT testing.

sec.title: Principle of measurement and experimental setup
sec.p: The “multilayer WVT” method is shown in Figure 1. The experimental system includes assemblies with each test specimen set and sealed into a custom ring. The seal consists of a bead of wax along the edge of the specimen and the test dish to impart airtightness. Each assembly separated with a rubber gasket is stacked vertically so that the adjacent specimens are spaced by an equally thick air layer. The assemblies are clamped together to provide an airtight system.

caption.p: Schematic of the multilayer system with five simultaneously tested specimens.

sec.p: The ring assemblies include machined slots for mounting wireless RH/T sensors within 1 mm of the top and bottom specimen surfaces. The RH/T sensors are mounted into custom metal brackets and are then mounted in the slots of the ring assemblies (Figure 2). The clamped system is placed on analytical balance for the duration of the experiment and the mass readings are continuously recorded. On the basis of recorded change in mass, elapsed time, and surface area of the specimen, fluxes are calculated. The RH/T sensors provide real-time RH/T data which is used to calculate vapor pressure at the top and bottom surfaces of each specimen.

caption.p: Two subassemblies clamped together. The components of the test setup include (1) prefabricated nylon ring, (2) specimen, (3) wax seal, (4) butyl rubber gasket, (5) wireless (RH/T) sensors, and (6) clamps.
RH/T: temperature and relative humidity.

sec.p: A GF Series, model GF-2000 analytical balance (manufactured by A&D) having 2000 g capacity and 0.01 g resolution, was used. The wireless sensors utilize Sensirion, Model SHT15 RH/T module with (a) the temperature resolution of 0.01°C and ±0.3°C accuracy at 25°C and (b) the RH resolution of 0.05% and ±2% accuracy for a range of RH between 20%–80% and ±4% accuracy for a range of RH between 0%–10% and 90%–100%. To maintain steady boundary conditions, the test assembly was placed in an environmental chamber with controlled temperature, RH, and air velocity. The test chamber is a custom design for a narrow range RH/T control of ±0.1°C and 1% RH. To maintain uniform conditions the chamber was equipped with a low-velocity centrifugal fan. At the time of chamber commissioning air, velocity measurements were performed to characterize the spatial velocity distribution. Except for the boundary layer, the air velocity in the chamber ranged from 0.23 to 0.24 m s−1.

sec.title: Precision, accuracy, bias, and measurement uncertainty
sec.p: The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) International defines a number of terms relevant to the measurement process including precision, accuracy, and bias. Precision is defined as a degree of agreement between individual measurements and Accuracy is defined as a closeness of agreement between the measured value and the true value (ASTM E631, 2006). While precision gives an indication on the closeness of values in repeated measurements, it provides no indication on the closeness of these values to the true value. When discussing precision, two additional concepts must be introduced, namely, repeatability (within laboratory precision) and reproducibility (between laboratory precision). The former defines the variability in measurement performed within a single laboratory by the same experimenter using the same equipment, procedures, and conditions. The latter defines the variability between measurements (single-test result with replicate specimens) performed in different laboratories and different individuals. Finally, a systematic error that contributes to the difference between the mean of the measured value and an accepted reference or true value is defined as Bias. The terms and definitions discussed to this point relate to the method of measurement. At a more fundamental level, there are uncertainties associated with a measurement process in each individual quantity. Whether it be mass, temperature, area, or partial pressure of water vapor, all quantities that are measured have associated uncertainties that characterize the spread of values for each quantity. Because all measurements are subject to uncertainty and a measured value becomes complete if it is accompanied by a statement of the associated uncertainty. It becomes imperative to determine the uncertainty associated with the multilayer test.

The difference between the measurement uncertainty and either precision or bias as defined by ASTM may vary because the actual operators may perform the measurement with different degree of consistence.

sec.title: Uncertainty analysis model
sec.p: In the multilayer WVT test, uncertainty analysis was critical because the RH/T measured on the opposing specimen surfaces are used to calculate the driving potential for vapor transport. In multilayer testing, this difference is typically narrow; without uncertainty analysis we have no confidence in the calculated results and the true value of the measured quantities. The premise of the multilayer approach is to simultaneously test as many specimens as possible. However, the overall uncertainty may place some constraints and limit the number of specimens tested. With each additional specimen added to the assembly, the resistance to the flow of moisture is increased and the difference in the driving potential across each layer also decreases. As the uncertainty increases and approaches the accuracy of the instruments used to perform measurements (i.e. RH/T sensors), the uncertainty propagation may contribute to the calculated transport coefficient being as high as the uncertainty. This must be considered during the selection of the instrumentation and the development of the test procedure.
In quantifying the overall uncertainty for an experiment includes the following steps:

list-item.p: Identify, quantify, and represent each source of uncertainty as a standard uncertainty.
Calculate the combined standard uncertainty by merging the square root of the sum of the squares for individual uncertainties.

Apply the uncertainty propagation equation to account for multiple sources of uncertainty. In order to combine uncertainties from various sources having different units, “sensitivity coefficients” are introduced to express all uncertainties in the same units.

Calculate the expanded uncertainty by multiplying the combined standard uncertainty and the coverage factor (k = 2). This value represents a confidence interval with a 95% probability that the true value of the measured quantity is included.

sec.p: In this approach, the uncertainty contributions are expressed in the same units and the same level of confidence and thus can be combined. All contributions are converted into standard uncertainties, that is, having a confidence level of plus or minus one standard deviation (SD).

The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurements established by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is one accepted reference that can be applied to uncertainty analysis. The Guide identifies that all sources of uncertainty (u) fall into two categories—either Type A or Type B (ISO, 1993). Uncertainty estimates stemming from statistical analysis typically based on repeated experimental readings fall into the former category (Type A) and are calculated according to the following formula (ISO, 1993)
where n is the number of measurements in the set and s is the estimated SD.

Uncertainty estimates determined from past experience, manufacturer’s specification/data sheets, calibration certificates, or published information fall into the latter category (Type B) (ISO, 1993). Assuming a rectangular distribution, the standard uncertainty can be expressed by the following formula
where a is the semirange (half-width) between the upper and lower limits.

sec.title: Uncertainty propagation
sec.p: The total or combined uncertainty for the experiment must include the component uncertainties from all contributing sources. In the case when all parameters in the test are independent, the uncertainty propagation equation is expressed as follows
This uncertainty propagation equation is based on a first-order Taylor series approximation for the output parameter (y) analyzed.

sec.title: Basic sources of uncertainty
sec.p: In typical measurements whether they be temperature or RH, sources that contribute to a combined uncertainty can be categorized into four groups: (a) imported uncertainties, (b) instrument/equipment uncertainties, (c) uncertainties occurring during measurements, and (d) other miscellaneous uncertainties. All possible uncertainties in the aforementioned sources must be carefully identified. Uncertainties listed on the calibration certificates for the instruments utilized in the experiment account for the imported uncertainties. The calibration certificate provided by the manufacturer for any equipment used, such as sensors and analytical balance, lists the required information. The second source, the instrument uncertainties, includes factors that affect the operation of the instrument and include but are not limited to repeatability, resolution, linearity, thermal coefficient, and drift. The uncertainty values for each factor are listed in the specification documents provided by the manufacturer of the device. In the multilayer test, these factors and the corresponding uncertainties for all instruments utilized including the analytical balance and wireless (RH/T) sensors must be identified, quantified, and included in the calculation of total uncertainty for the experiment.

The third source of uncertainties is attributed mainly to fluctuations in conditions during the time of the measurements. Typically, in the traditional WVT “cup” test method, the cup containing either desiccant (dry cup) or water (wet cup) is temporarily removed from the chamber for weighing. During this process, the boundary condition equilibrium is disturbed when the cup is moved from the environmental chamber to the laboratory space environment. Moving the cup even a short distance from the tested environment to the analytical balance agitates the desiccant or the water which temporarily affects the local vapor pressures leading to driving potential fluctuations in testing. This may not be a significant source of uncertainty if gravimetric readings are obtained infrequently. However, increasing the incidence of weight measurements (i.e. several per hour for the entire test duration) so that the time required to reestablish the driving potential approaches the frequency of readings may be a significant source of uncertainty. Particularly, in multilayer testing with several specimens and multiple boundary layers, such uncertainties can be propagated, thus introducing further unknowns.

Because the source of uncertainty can have a significant impact and cannot easily be quantified, it is best to minimize or eliminate them whenever possible. The multilayer test procedure is designed to eliminate this source of uncertainty from the experiment. The setup remains stationary on the analytical balance and is undisturbed for the duration of the test. The balance records weights automatically at preprogrammed frequency without the need to move the test assembly to obtain readings. All other remaining sources of uncertainty identified but not included in the above categories are treated as miscellaneous uncertainties. The measurements of specimen diameter (for use in surface area calculation) are an example of such sources of uncertainty. Not all sources of uncertainty become pertinent to the analysis. For example, since RH/T are measured on both surfaces of the specimen, the air layer between the adjacent specimens is irrelevant and the uncertainty attributed to the air layer thickness is not considered.

sec.title: Uncertainty in weight measurements
sec.p: The component uncertainties in weight measurements obtained using an analytical balance must consider the following factors; readability, repeatability, linearity, temperature coefficient (sensitivity to drift), and uncertainty from the balance calibration report. The values for parameters listed in Table 1 are included in the manufacturer’s specification and because these are not obtained from repeated measurements, a rectangular distribution is assumed for all factors with the exception of the balance calibration. Table 1 lists these factors, their corresponding values, the type of statistical distribution selected, the calculated standard uncertainty (um), and the relative contribution for each factor to the total uncertainty.

sec.title: Uncertainty for temperature
sec.p: The component uncertainties in temperature measurements performed using the wireless RH/T sensors consider the following factors: resolution, repeatability, linearity, drift, temperature effects, chamber temperature fluctuations, and instrument calibration. The values for parameters listed in Table 2 are included in the manufacturer’s specification, and because these are not obtained from repeated measurements, rectangular distribution is assumed for most factors. Chamber temperature fluctuations and instrument calibration are treated as normal distribution because these are determined from repeated measurements. Table 2 lists these factors, their corresponding values, the type of statistical distribution, the standard uncertainty (utem), and the relative contribution for each factor to the total uncertainty.

sec.p: The component uncertainties in RH measurements performed using the wireless RH/T sensors consider the following factors: resolution, repeatability, linearity, drift, humidity fluctuations, and instrument calibration. sec.title: Uncertainty for miscellaneous sources
sec.p: The uncertainties that stem from miscellaneous sources include uncertainties in measuring the diameter of surface area exposed to transport of water vapor. This means that the measurement excludes the portion of the specimen covered by sealant along its edge. Table 4 lists the corresponding values, the type of statistical distribution, the standard uncertainty, and the relative contribution for each factor to the total uncertainty. Since RH/T measured on each side of the specimen are used in calculations, the thickness of the air layers between adjacent specimens as well as the bottommost specimen and the water in the bottom cup are not considered.

sec.title: Uncertainty for saturated vapor pressure
sec.p: The difference in partial pressure of water vapor constitutes the driving potential for the transport of water vapor. In multilayer WVT tests, the sensors measure RH/T at the opposing specimen surfaces and the collected data must be used to determine the uncertainty for the partial pressure of water vapor. The partial pressure for water vapor (Pv) is determined from equation (4) by multiplying the saturated vapor pressure (Psat) and the RH measured by the sensors (see Appendix 1 for nomenclature)
The saturated vapor pressure is calculated using equation (5) and it is a function of absolute temperature (T) expressed in degree Kelvin as indicated in equation (6) (ASHRAE, 2009):
The measured air temperature is converted to absolute temperature with the following equation
With the mean air temperature of (23.0°C) at the uppermost sensor in the experimental assembly, the T and Psat are calculated

At this stage, the uncertainty in temperature measurements is introduced. The temperature is measured using wireless RH/T sensors and the total uncertainty (utem) from component sources is determined and reported in Table 2. Since the manufacturer’s specifications list the accuracy for the sensor, it is important to verify whether this constitutes a higher source of uncertainty (utem,man) (Shi et al., 2007). For the wireless sensor utilized, the accuracy is listed at ±0.3°C. Assuming a normal distribution and 95% confidence level, the uncertainty for the temperature sensor, as reported by the manufacturer, is equal to 0.3/1.96 = 0.15°C ≈ 0.15 K (Shi et al., 2007). The uncertainty for temperature determined from the manufacturer’s listed accuracy, (utem,man), is lower than (utem) in Table 2, and (utem) should be used in determining the uncertainty for saturated vapor pressure.
By introducing the uncertainty propagation equation (3) shown below and applying it to equation (5)
and taking the derivative with respect to (T), the uncertainty for saturated vapor pressure is calculated as follows

sec.title: Uncertainty for RH
sec.p: Similarly to the temperature measurements, the RH is measured using the same wireless RH/T sensors, and the uncertainty from this source is determined and reported in Table 3. The sensor accuracy provided by the manufacturer in the instrument specifications is ±2.0%. Assuming a normal distribution and 95% confidence level, the uncertainty for the RH sensor (uRH,man) determined from manufacturer’s specification is 2/1.96 = 1.02%. The uncertainty for RH determined from the manufacturer’s listed accuracy (uRH,man) is lower than (uRH) in Table 3, and (uRH) should be used in determining the uncertainty for the partial pressure of water vapor.

sec.title: Uncertainty for partial pressure of water vapor
sec.p: The uncertainty for the partial pressure of water vapor is calculated as the next step. As noted earlier, the vapor pressure is a function of temperature and can be calculated by multiplying saturation vapor pressure and the fraction of RH. For ambient air with 23°C temperature and 50% RH, the saturation vapor pressure and corresponding partial pressure of water vapor are given as follows
By introducing the uncertainty propagation equation (3) shown below and applying it into equation (4), the uncertainty for partial pressure of water vapor can be calculated

Since the multilayer WVT is conducted with 50% RH in the free air stream and 100% RH assumed at the surface of the water. The conditions on the boundaries of all specimens are between this range. Assuming that the temperature is constant throughout the test, the uncertainty for the partial pressures of water vapor corresponding to the measured RH on each boundary of the specimen is calculated. The uncertainty is plotted as a function of RH to determine the curve fit shown in Figure 3. A second-order polynomial equation was used to generate the curve fit and the equation. This equation, in turn, was used to calculate the uncertainty for measured RH in the experiment.

caption.p: Uncertainty for uncertainty for the partial pressures of water vapor plotted as a function of RH.
RH: relative humidity.

sec.p: The equation from the curve fit is now used to calculate the uncertainty for partial pressure of water vapor from the RH measured by each RH/T sensor in multilayer WVT tests with four, three, and two material specimens. The mean RH following the onset of steady state is used in this calculation and these are listed in Table 5.

The driving potential for water vapor transport is determined from the difference in partial pressure of water vapor across the tested material. Since this difference is determined by subtracting the partial pressure of water vapor on opposing surface of the specimen as shown in equation (9), the uncertainties for the two partial pressures of water vapor is combined in equation (10) to generate the uncertainty for the difference in a partial pressure of water vapor (

Substituting the values from Table 6 into equation (10) generates the uncertainty for a difference in partial pressure of water vapor for all tested specimens. These differences are listed in Table 7.

sec.title: Uncertainty in weight measurements
sec.p: The uncertainty for the mass difference is determined in a similar way. Having determined the uncertainty for mass difference, the uncertainty for mass flow rate is calculated which represents the weight change in time. The weight of the test setup and the time of the readings were recorded automatically throughout the full test duration by the analytical balance. The uncertainty attributed to the time of recording is negligible. Thus, the difference in weight is the remaining source of uncertainty. The weight difference is determined following the onset of steady state during a 24-h test period.

where m1 and m2 represent the change in weight at the onset and at the end of the test period, respectively. The uncertainty associated with each weight measurement has been calculated in Table 1 and it is 3.0151E-05 kg. Since the same analytical balance is used for both measurements, equation (12) can be simplified as noted below. Substituting the uncertainty for a single-weight measurement into equation (12), the uncertainty for the difference in weights is determined

The uncertainty in mass flow rate
(
u
Qm
)
is calculated by dividing the uncertainty for the difference in weight
(
u
Δ m
)
by the duration of the test (e.g. 24 h which is 86,400 s) to generate the mass flow rate. The uncertainty for mass flow rate
(
u
Qm
)
then becomes 4.9352E-10 (kg s−1).

sec.title: Uncertainty in diameter measurements
sec.p: The surface area calculation contributes to the total uncertainty. When circular specimens are used, the radius or diameter of the specimen must be known to complete the calculation. If digital calipers are used in measurements, then components of uncertainty include similar parameters as for any other digital device such as resolution, repeatability, linearity, and thermal drift. In instances when nondigital calipers are used, the parameters listed above are excluded. The uncertainty for diameter measurements is listed in Table 4. The uncertainty attributed to the measurements of air layer thickness between adjacent specimens as well as between the surface of the water and the first specimen in the test assembly is irrelevant to the analysis because in this approach the temperature and the RH are measured on the opposing sides.

sec.title: Combining the uncertainty sources
sec.p: This is a critical step in the completion of the analysis. All pertinent sources of uncertainty are combined into a single value which represents the uncertainty for each layer in a multilayer WVT test. The sources included in the combined uncertainty are listed in equation (13) and include uncertainty components from a difference in mass flow rate, difference in partial pressure of water vapor, and diameter measurements. Before the component uncertainties are combined, all values must have the same units. This is achieved by multiplying each component of uncertainty by a sensitivity coefficient (ci)
The sensitivity coefficient is calculated from the equations listed below

Tables 8 to 16 summarize the input estimates (xi), sensitivity coefficients (ci), standard uncertainties (uc(xi)) for m, A, and ΔP. The last two columns of each table provide the absolute contributions of each component uncertainty for each layer in the multilayer WVT test with two, three, and four specimens. The last row on the left side of the table lists the calculated water vapor permeance from the measured data. The last row on the right side of the table lists the expanded uncertainty with a 95% confidence level. As an example in Table 8, the calculated water vapor permeance of 4.28E-09 (kg m−2 s−1·Pa−1) (75 Perm) should be reported with an expanded uncertainty of 1.316E-09 (kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1) (23 Perm). This means that the true water vapor permeance has a 95% probability of being within 4.28E-09 ± 1.316E-09 (kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1) (75 ± 23 Perm).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The calculated water vapor permeance, the expanded uncertainty, and the percent error for the three series of tests are summarized in Table 17. The results show that the largest uncertainty in each test is attributed to the top specimen in the assembly. This is expected because the top layer is often subjected to boundary condition effects from the air stream in the chamber. RH/T fluctuations as well as flowing air likely causing a degree of convection and membrane fluttering, which reduce the difference in partial pressure across the top layer.

caption.p: Summary of calculated water vapor permeance from experimental measurements and the expanded uncertainties for each specimen in a two-, three-, and four-layer multilayer WVT test

tr.th: Calculated water vapor permeance (kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1)

fn.label: a
fn.p: The top layer in the assembly test.

sec.p: Excluding the uppermost specimens from the analysis, the expanded uncertainty for the remaining tests ranges from 31% to 60% of the calculated permeance. For test on two and three layers, the expanded uncertainty ranges from 31% to 45%. At first glance, these values appear quite large; however, they must be compared to an expected error in traditional WVT.

In North America, WVT of construction materials including membrane-type materials such as weather-resistive barriers is performed in accordance with the ASTM E96:2010 (2010) Standard. Originally, developed for application with low-permeance materials, the standard has become an accepted approach for testing permeable and semipermeable materials. As indicated above, the topmost layer in a multilayer WVT test method is problematic and may be influenced by the boundary layer effects. Similar effects will influence the single-layer WVT tests conducted in accordance with the ASTM E96:2010 (2010) test method. The ASTM standard does not prescribe that RH measurements be taken during testing and it is typically assumed that the RH remains close to 100%. The standard includes correction for the added resistance of the air gap between the lower surface of the tested specimen and the surface of the water. This equation for the “still air layer correction” does not account for buoyant or convective effects that may influence the transport. The authors conducted a WVT test with a single layer of the same material as used in the multilayer tests. The wet cup method was applied in testing following the procedure and corrections outlined in the ASTM E96:2010 (2010) Standard. The authors assumed that uncertainties in the weight change measurements and diameter measurements of the specimen remain unchanged. However, with the assumption that RH remains at 100%, the uncertainty in partial pressure of water vapor was recalculated. Table 18 includes calculated water vapor permeance, the expanded uncertainty, and the percent error for a wet cup WVT test conducted with a single material layer. The calculated permeance is 9.99E-09 (kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1) (174 Perm) and the expanded uncertainty is 3.75E-08 (kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1) (174 Perm). The percent error determined by dividing uncertainty by permeance is 656%. The expanded uncertainty with a 95% confidence level is higher than the calculated permeance.

caption.p: Combined uncertainty for a single-layer WVT test conducted in accordance with ASTM E96:2010 (2010) test procedure

tr.th:
| u
(
c

c

|
(kg m−2 s−1 Pa−1)

sec.p: The results in Tables 8 to 16 show the combined component uncertainties for mass flow rate, area determination, and difference in the partial pressure of water vapor. The highest source of uncertainty stems from the difference in the partial pressure of water vapor which is calculated from the measured RH/T. The validity of the calculated uncertainty is affected by the accuracy of the sensors. Obviously, the experimenter aims for the lowest possible expanded uncertainty because the lower the value, the more meaningful the results and greater the level of confidence that the results fall within a range of expected certainty. The dilemma faced by the experimenter is that the sensors must be as accurate as possible and yet compact enough to fit into the air space without obstructing the path for mass flow. Given the practical limitations of the test method, equipment, and the error(s) that may be attributed to the traditional approach, the expanded uncertainty reported by the authors in this article is lower than that expanded uncertainty that would be determined for the traditional approach in which large uncertainty stems from the assumed boundary conditions at the water surface.

Another complexity in testing WVT of highly permeable materials is that the rate of water vapor generation from the free water surface in the test cup may be lower than the rate of WVT through the material. In this instance, the supply of water vapor in the air gap below the specimen is lower than transport, and a steep gradient in partial pressure of water vapor is likely created just above the water surface. This is another reason why authors decided to measure the boundary conditions.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: When performing multilayer WVT test, several parameters including but not limited to the range of expected transport for the material, the accuracy of the instrumentation used, and the ability to control the boundary conditions within a required range must be considered. When selecting a number of layers for testing, prior knowledge of expected permeance or experience-based insight is necessary to estimate the optimum number of layers for testing. The authors report analysis of tests performed with two, three, and four layers. However, additional tests with 5 through 10 specimens were also conducted. The results are not reported because the expanded uncertainty exceeded the calculated water vapor permeance. At some point, the difference in partial pressure of water vapor approaches the uncertainty in the boundary condition and the results are meaningless. When testing thin and flexible materials having high permeance (e.g. in excess of 50 Perm), the boundary effects during testing must be taken into considerations. These effects are very difficult to quantify; however, the impact is likely large enough to warrant their recognition. Since some weather-resistive membranes are thin and flexible, the airflow in the environment chamber above the uppermost specimens may be creating a level of turbulence that impacts the mass transport through the top specimen. This airflow is likely contributing to increased convection in the air space between the two uppermost specimens and may also cause the top specimen to flutter. The corrections for these effects cannot be quantified and thus the top specimen should be used as a buffer layer to reduce these effects on the remaining layers. The results of multilayer testing highlight another significant point that the air layer below the uppermost specimens is likely not still air. The level of convection in the air layer, however, cannot be quantified with the current measurement technology. This is one of the reasons why authors opted out to measure RH/T on the opposing specimen surfaces.

The multilayer test results provide the functional dependence of WVT on the RH. It is beneficial to include more layers and obtain more points to achieve better curve fit. However, as more specimens are stacked in a multilayer test, the vapor pressure difference across each specimen may be below the RH/T accuracy of the sensor. This means that the calculated uncertainty in the difference of partial pressure of water vapor may be larger than the calculated value. There is a balance between the largest number of specimens tested simultaneously and the minimum difference in the partial pressure of water vapor across the specimen layers. When developing a multilayer WVT tests, these factors must be carefully scrutinized.
